images.caption: Figure 1:The primary objective of our framework is to learn the transport from the marginal distribution to the data distribution. Based on it we propose two optimization objectives: velocity matching and velocity distillation. Velocity matching directly supervisesϕθ\boldsymbol{\phi}_{\theta}via matching the velocity fields between the student and teacher (Eq.13), while velocity distillation indirectly supervisesϕθ\boldsymbol{\phi}_{\theta}via matching the marginal distributions between the student and teacher (Eq.17).
Figure 2:Qualitative results of FlashVDM[28], the teacher model TRELLIS[81], and our method. Since FlashVDM does not generate the appearance of 3D assets, we compare with FlashVDM only on geometry.
Figure 3:Qualitative results with and without distillation during few-step inference.
Figure 4:Qualitative comparison on CM[66], PCM[74], sCM[43]and ours. Our method exhibits the most complete and fine-grained geometric and visual details.
Figure 5:Qualitative results of ablation studies on our proposed two loss functions.
Figure 6:Our 3D Gaussians[25]and mesh generation results. Odd rows and even rows represent samples from22steps×2\times 2and11step×2\times 2during inference, respectively.
Figure 7:Our 3D Gaussians[25]and mesh generation results. Odd rows and even rows represent samples from22steps×2\times 2and11step×2\times 2during inference, respectively.
